[H1] Type I Diabetes.

[LIST_ITEM] Diabetes Mellitus: systemic disease with multiple metabolic abnormalities, mainly elevation in plasma glucose (lipid metabolism, ketones)
[LIST_ITEM] Classification
[LIST_ITEM] Type I
[LIST_ITEM] A. Immune Mediated - 85%
[LIST_ITEM] B. Idiopathic - 15%
[LIST_ITEM] Type II
[LIST_ITEM] Other types (MODY, secondary DM)

[LIST_ITEM] Signs of Type I: Polyuria; Polydipsia (thirst); Polyphagia (hunger); weight loss; fatigue; increased frequency of infections; rapid onset (type II is much slower progressing); insulin dependent; early onset
[LIST_ITEM] Differences between type I and II: type I has islet cell antibodies and patients are typically thin
[LIST_ITEM] HLA related genetic background, no insulin secretion, non-insulin resistant, non-responsive to oral meds, ketosis prone
[LIST_ITEM] Type I is only 5% (1.5-2mm cases)
[LIST_ITEM] Type I is chronic autoimmune disease but can also develop in adults/elderly
[LIST_ITEM] Polygenic: HLA linkage, non-MHC genes
[LIST_ITEM] Autoimmune etiology: antibodies to islet autoantigens, autoreactive T cells
[LIST_ITEM] Immune modulation alters course: antigen vaccination, general immunosuppression
[LIST_ITEM] Graph on pg. 297
[LIST_ITEM] Will see multiple antibodies during beta cell injury phase
[LIST_ITEM] Declining beta cell mass
[LIST_ITEM] Loss of first phase insulin response (pre-diabetes)
[LIST_ITEM] Diabetes full blown once mass is below 10%
[LIST_ITEM] Type I
[LIST_ITEM] Insulin resistance
[LIST_ITEM] β cell hypertrophy
[LIST_ITEM] Islet inflammation, pathogenic T cells, β cell decomposition
[LIST_ITEM] Impaired glucose tolerance
[LIST_ITEM] Autoimmune diabetes, insulitis, β cell death
[LIST_ITEM] Genetic Links
[LIST_ITEM] Lifetime empiric risk increases w/ close relatives
[LIST_ITEM] Father has greater effect than mother --> imprinting
[LIST_ITEM] HLA class II genes have highest incidence
[LIST_ITEM] HLA complex: (DQ2, DQ8), DR3, DR4 are most associated w/ Type I
[LIST_ITEM] Sibling sharing 2 HLA haplotypes w/ type I affected sibling at much higher risk of developing
[LIST_ITEM] Multiple factors
[LIST_ITEM] Autoreactive T cells --> islet autoantibodies (not shown to directly kill β cells)
[LIST_ITEM] Elevated cytokines (IFNγ, IL-1β, TNFα, etc.)
[LIST_ITEM] Increased apoptosis/necrosis, decreased neogenesis
[LIST_ITEM] Hyperglycemia --> glucose toxicity
